sen.j: 允恭天皇（いんぎょうてんのう、仁徳天皇64年（376年）? - 允恭天皇42年1月14日 (旧暦)（453年2月8日））は、第19代の天皇（在位：允恭天皇元年12月 (旧暦)（413年1月） - 同42年1月14日 (旧暦)（453年2月8日））。
sen.e: Emperor Ingyo (376?-February 8, 453) was the nineteenth Emperor who was in the reign from January 413 to February 8, 453.
Emperor Ingyo (circa 376 - February 8, 453) was the nineteenth Emperor of Japan (reigned from January, 413, to February 8, 453).
sen.cmt: 日付書式を修正しました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文に補足しました。
sen.e: Emperor Ingyo (circa 376 - February 8, 453) was the nineteenth Emperor of Japan (reigned from January, 413, to February 8, 453).

sen.j: 雄朝津間稚子宿禰尊（おあさづまわくごのすくねのみこと）、男浅津間若子宿禰王（古事記）。
sen.e: His names include Oasazumawakugo no Sukune no mikoto and Oasazumawakugo no Sukune no miko ("Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters)).
His names include Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no mikoto and Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no miko (according to "Kojiki" [literally, The Records of Ancient Matters]).
sen.cmt: 用語・形式上の修正を施しました
sen.e: His names include Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no mikoto and Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no miko (according to "Kojiki" [literally, The Records of Ancient Matters]).

sen.j: 中国の歴史書『宋書』・『梁書』に記される倭の五王中の倭王済に比定されている。
sen.e: He is identified with the king of Wa, Sai, of the five kings of Wa, described in the Chinese history books, "Sungshu" (Book of the Sung dynasty) and "Book of Liang dynasty."

He is identified with the king of Wa (supposedly, Japan), King Sai, of the five kings of Wa, described in the Chinese history books, "So-jo" (which is known as "Sung-shu" in Chinese or the Book of Song [one of the Southern Dynasties of China]) and "Ryo-jo" (known as "Liang-shu" in Chinese or the Book of Liang).
sen.cmt: スペーシングを修正、および用語を補足修正しました。宋書：http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=6TADbQ8_b8gC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=Sung+shu&source=bl&ots=UhBmKCtYrk&sig=qrPcgxGUif0jdlAmZbLFGH-q404&hl=ja&ei=N7RsTImwEMPIcdf32aEB&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=12&ved=0CEAQ6AEwCw#v=onepage&q=Sung%20shu&f=false 梁書：http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=6TADbQ8_b8gC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=Sung+shu&source=bl&ots=UhBmKCtYrk&sig=qrPcgxGUif0jdlAmZbLFGH-q404&hl=ja&ei=N7RsTImwEMPIcdf32aEB&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=12&ved=0CEAQ6AEwCw#v=onepage&q=Liang&f=false
sen.e: He is identified with the king of Wa (supposedly, Japan), King Sai, of the five kings of Wa, described in the Chinese history books, "So-jo" (which is known as "Sung-shu" in Chinese or the Book of Song [one of the Southern Dynasties of China]) and "Ryo-jo" (known as "Liang-shu" in Chinese or the Book of Liang).

sen.j: 仁徳天皇の第四皇子。
sen.e: He was the fourth Prince of Emperor Nintoku.
Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no miko (the future Emperor Ingyo) was the fourth son (prince) of Emperor Nintoku.
sen.cmt: 曖昧さ回避の補足を施しました
sen.e: Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no miko (the future Emperor Ingyo) was the fourth son (prince) of Emperor Nintoku.

sen.j: 母は葛城襲津彦の女・磐之媛命（いわのひめのみこと）
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko, Iwanohimenomikoto.
His mother was a daughter of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko, whose name was Iwanohime no mikoto.
sen.cmt: スペーシング修正・曖昧さ回避の補足を施しました
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko, whose name was Iwanohime no mikoto.

sen.j: 履中天皇、反正天皇の同母弟。
sen.e: He was a younger brother-uterine of Emperors Richu and Hanzei.
He was a younger brother of Emperors Richu and Hanzei.
He was a younger brother of Emperors Richu and Hanzei.

sen.j: 皇居
sen.e: Palace
Imperial Palace
Imperial Palace

sen.j: 都は遠飛鳥宮（とおつあすかのみや、現在の奈良県高市郡明日香村飛鳥か）。
sen.e: The capital was founded in Asuka (presumably, present-day Asuka, Asuka Village, Takaichi County, Nara Prefecture)
sen.cmt: 「飛鳥」を「とおつあすかのみや」と呼んでいますが、この読みに当てはまる漢字は「遠飛鳥宮」ですので、ここでの訳は、単に「あすか」としました。
sen.e: It was Totsu asuka no miya Palace in the capital (located presumably in present-day Asuka, Asuka-mura Village, Takaichi-gun County, Nara Prefecture.)
sen.cmt: 原文のリンク先表示を修正のうえ再訳出しました。「都は」は「都の」の古語的表現と解釈しました
sen.e: It was Totsu asuka no miya Palace in the capital (located presumably in present-day Asuka, Asuka-mura Village, Takaichi-gun County, Nara Prefecture.)

sen.j: 飛鳥の地に宮を設けた初めての天皇が允恭であった。
sen.e: The first Emperor to establish a palace on the land of Asuka was Ingyo.
The first Emperor who built a palace in Asuka was Ingyo.
The first Emperor who built a palace in Asuka was Ingyo.

tit.cmt: 統一用語に修正しました

sen.j: 以下、『日本書紀』に拠る。
sen.e: The followings are based on "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
The followings are based on "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
The followings are based on "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 反正天皇5年1月（410年2月）、反正天皇が皇太子を定めずして崩御したため、群臣達が相談して雄朝津間稚子宿禰尊を天皇（大王）に推挙する。
sen.e: Because Emperor Hanzei passed away in February 410 without naming the Crown Prince, a crowd of the retainers conferred together and recommended Oasazumawakugo no Sukune no mikoto as the Emperor (okimi).
Since Emperor Hanzei passed away in February, 410, without naming the Crown Prince, a crowd of retainers conferred together and recommended Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no mikoto as the Emperor (okimi).
sen.cmt: 形式上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: Since Emperor Hanzei passed away in February, 410, without naming the Crown Prince, a crowd of retainers conferred together and recommended Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no mikoto as the Emperor (okimi).

sen.j: 尊は病気を理由に再三辞退して空位が続いたが、允恭天皇元年12月（413年1月）、忍坂大中姫の強い要請を受け即位。
sen.e: He repeatedly refused to accept on the ground of illness and vacancy of the throne continued but, in January 413, upon strong request from Oshisakano onakatsunohimeno mikoto, he acceded to the throne.

He repeatedly refused to accept the emperorship on the ground of being ill, so that the throne remained vacant, but in January, 413, upon strong request from Oshisaka no onakatsu hime no mikoto, he finally acceded to the throne.
sen.cmt: 形式および表現上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: He repeatedly refused to accept the emperorship on the ground of being ill, so that the throne remained vacant, but in January, 413, upon strong request from Oshisaka no onakatsu hime no mikoto, he finally acceded to the throne.

sen.j: 3年8月（413年9月）、新羅から医者を招聘、天皇の病気を治療する。
sen.e: In September 413, a doctor was invited from Silla (ancient Korean kingdom) to treat illness of the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 「（允恭）3年（413年）8月」は允恭を正として換暦すると414年9月になります（413年は誤りと思われます）が、年は原文通りとしました。
sen.e: In September, 413, a doctor was invited from Silla (ancient Korean kingdom) to treat illness of the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 形式上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: In September, 413, a doctor was invited from Silla (ancient Korean kingdom) to treat illness of the Emperor.

sen.j: 4年9月（415年10月）、諸氏族の氏姓の乱れを正すため、飛鳥甘樫丘にて盟神探湯（くがたち）を実施する。
sen.e: In October 416, in order to resolve confusion of the system of clans and hereditary titles among various clans, he carried out kugatachi (a way of decision by putting one's hand in hot water) at Amakashi no oka Hill in Asuka.

In October, 416, in order to resolve a confusion in the Uji-kabane system (the system of clans and hereditary titles) among various clans, the Emperor carried out Kugatachi ordeal (also known as kukatachi or kukadachi, which refers to hot-water ordeal) at Amakashi no oka Hill in Asuka.
sen.cmt: 形式・用語・表現上の修正を加えました。原文にリンク先表示（ウジカバネ）がありましたので修正しました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: In October, 416, in order to resolve a confusion in the Uji-kabane system (the system of clans and hereditary titles) among various clans, the Emperor carried out Kugatachi ordeal (also known as kukatachi or kukadachi, which refers to hot-water ordeal) at Amakashi no oka Hill in Asuka.

sen.j: 5年7月（416年8月）、玉田宿禰（葛城襲津彦の孫）の叛意が露顕、これを誅殺する。
sen.e: In August, 416, the will of Tamada no sukune (grandson of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko) to rebel became exposed and the Emperor had him killed.
In August, 416, Tamada no sukune (grandson of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko) turned out to be rebellious, and the Emperor punished him by death.
sen.cmt: 形式および表現上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しましたの。
sen.e: In August, 416, Tamada no sukune (grandson of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko) turned out to be rebellious, and the Emperor punished him by death.

sen.j: 7年12月（419年1月）、皇后の妹・衣通郎姫を入内させるが、皇后の不興を買い、藤原宮（奈良県橿原市）に住まわせる。
sen.e: In January 419, he made Sotooshinoiratsume, a younger sister of the Empress, enter into court, but this fell under displeasure of the Empress, and he made iratsume live in Fujiwara Palace (in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).

In January, 419, the Emperor made Sotooshi (also read Sotoori) no iratsume, a younger sister of the Empress, enter into court (which was called judai, meaning an imperial consort's bridal entry into court), but this fell under the Empress's displeasure, and he made Sotooshi no iratsume live in the Fujiwara no miya Palace (in present-day Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 形式および表現上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: In January, 419, the Emperor made Sotooshi (also read Sotoori) no iratsume, a younger sister of the Empress, enter into court (which was called judai, meaning an imperial consort's bridal entry into court), but this fell under the Empress's displeasure, and he made Sotooshi no iratsume live in the Fujiwara no miya Palace (in present-day Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 8年2月（419年3月）、衣通郎姫が皇后の嫉妬を理由に茅渟宮（ちぬのみや、大阪府泉佐野市）へ移る。
sen.e: In March 419, Sotooshinoiratsume moved to Chinu no miya (in Izumisano City, Osaka Prefecture) because of jealousy of the Empress.
In March, 419, Sotooshi no iratsume who feared the jealous Empress moved to Chinu no miya Palace (in present-day Izumisano City, Osaka Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 形式および表現上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: In March, 419, Sotooshi no iratsume who feared the jealous Empress moved to Chinu no miya Palace (in present-day Izumisano City, Osaka Prefecture).

sen.j: 天皇は遊猟にかこつけて郎姫の許に行幸を続けたが、10年（421年）皇后に諌められ、その後の茅渟行幸は稀になった。
sen.e: Emperor continued the imperial visit to iratsume using hunting as his excuse but, in 421, he was warned by the Empress and thereafter he rarely visited Chinu.
sen.cmt: 「遊猟」は「猟」と解釈して訳しました。
sen.e: Emperor continued the imperial visit to iratsume using hunting as his excuse, but in 421, he was warned by the Empress, thereafter rarely visiting Chinu.
sen.cmt: 形式上の修正を加えました。
sen.e: Emperor continued the imperial visit to iratsume using hunting as his excuse, but in 421, he was warned by the Empress, thereafter rarely visiting Chinu.

sen.j: 24年6月（435年7月）、皇太子の木梨軽皇子と同母妹の軽大娘皇女の近親相姦が発覚。
sen.e: In July 435, an incestuous affair of the Crown Prince, Kinashi no karunomiko, with his younger sister-uterine, Karuno oiratsume, was brought to light.
In July, 435, an incest between the Crown Prince Kinashi no karu no miko and his younger sister, Karu no oiratsume, was brought to light.
sen.cmt: 形式および表現上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: In July, 435, an incest between the Crown Prince Kinashi no karu no miko and his younger sister, Karu no oiratsume, was brought to light.

sen.j: 軽大娘皇女を伊予国に配流（→衣通姫伝説）。
sen.e: Karuno oiratsume was exiled to Iyo Province (®Sotoorihime legend)
sen.cmt: （ ）内、→の意味が不詳ですが、原文通りにしました。
sen.e: Karu no oiratsume was exiled to Iyo Province (see Sotoori-hime legend)
sen.cmt: 形式上の修正を加えました
sen.e: Karu no oiratsume was exiled to Iyo Province (see Sotoori-hime legend)
He passed away in February 453.
He passed away in February, 453.
sen.cmt: 形式および表現上の修正を加えました。なお、旧暦を西暦換算したものを原文にも補足しました。
sen.e: He passed away in February, 453.

sen.j: 新羅王はこれを悲しみ、弔使を送る。
sen.e: The king of Silla mourned the demise and sent a messenger of condolence.
The king of Silla mourned the demise and sent a messenger of condolence.
The king of Silla mourned the demise and sent a messenger of condolence.

sen.j: 『古事記』『旧事紀』に78歳、『愚管抄』『神皇正統記』に80歳、北野本『日本書紀』に81歳（一本68歳）とする。
sen.e: His age at demise was 78 according to "Kojiki" and "Kujiki" (an ancient Japanese historical text), 80 according to "Gukansho" (Jottings of a Fool) and "Jinno Shotoki" (Chronicle of Gods and Sovereigns), and 81 according to the Kitano's book of "Nihonshoki" (68 according to some book cited therein).
sen.cmt: 「日本書紀に81歳（一本68歳）」中の「一本」は、日本書紀中の出典不記載の引用文献のことと解釈して訳しました。（参考）ウィキペディア「日本書紀」
sen.e: His age at demise was 78 according to "Kojiki" and "Kujiki" (an ancient Japanese historical text), 80 according to "Gukansho" (Jottings of a Fool) and "Jinno Shotoki" (Chronicle of Gods and Sovereigns), and 81 according to the Kitano manuscript (the Kitano Ms., Class I, owned by Kitano-tenmangu Shrine in Kyoto) of the "Nihonshoki" (68 according to the unknown reference cited therein).
sen.cmt: 形式・用語解釈・表現上の修正を加えました
sen.e: His age at demise was 78 according to "Kojiki" and "Kujiki" (an ancient Japanese historical text), 80 according to "Gukansho" (Jottings of a Fool) and "Jinno Shotoki" (Chronicle of Gods and Sovereigns), and 81 according to the Kitano manuscript (the Kitano Ms., Class I, owned by Kitano-tenmangu Shrine in Kyoto) of the "Nihonshoki" (68 according to the unknown reference cited therein).

tit.e: Theory of Emperor Ingyo being from Gozoku (a local ruling family)
A Theory of Emperor Ingyo Being Gozoku
tit.cmt: タイトルとして簡潔化しました
tit.e: A Theory of Emperor Ingyo Being Gozoku

sen.j: 允恭天皇の名には奇妙な点が存在する。
sen.e: There is some peculiar point in the name of Emperor Ingyo.
There is some peculiarity in the name of Emperor Ingyo.
There is some peculiarity in the name of Emperor Ingyo.

sen.j: すなわち、雄朝津間稚子宿禰尊（おあさづまわくごのすくねのみこと）に「宿禰」という皇族（王族）らしからぬ敬称が混ざっていることである。
sen.e: That is, in Oasazumawakugo no Sukune no mikoto, there is mingled the title of honor, 'Sukune,' which is not fitting for the Imperial Family (the royal family).
That is, his name Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no mikoto includes the title of honor, 'Sukune,' which does not fit for an Imperial (or royal) Family member.
sen.cmt: 形式・表現上の修正を加えました
sen.e: That is, his name Oasazuma wakugo no sukune no mikoto includes the title of honor, 'Sukune,' which does not fit for an Imperial (or royal) Family member.

sen.j: 宿禰（足尼とも書く）の称号は4世紀から6世紀にかけて、しばしば（王族ではない）有力豪族の名に下接して使われていた（例：野見宿禰・武内宿禰・多加利足尼など）。
sen.e: The title, Sukune (the third highest of the eight hereditary titles), was often used by adding after the name of influential local ruling families (who are not related to the royal family) (e.g., NOMI no Sukune, TAKENOUCHI no Sukune, TAKARI no Sukune, etc.).
sen.cmt: 「宿禰（足尼とも書く）」の（ ）内の注は読みは一緒で漢字が違うだけですので、訳は省略しました。また「多加利」は、「たかり」と読みました。
sen.e: The title Sukune (which was written as "宿禰" or "足尼" in Japanese) was, particularly from the fourth century to the sixth, often added after the name of influential gozoku (local ruling families, who are not related to the royal family) (e.g., NOMI no Sukune, TAKENOUCHI no Sukune, TAKARI no Sukune and so on).
sen.cmt: 宿禰の漢字表記の違いを補足しました。なお、補足解説にある八色の姓は684年成立である為この記事には該当せず、削除しました。形式・用語・表現上の修正を加えました。
sen.e: The title Sukune (which was written as "宿禰" or "足尼" in Japanese) was, particularly from the fourth century to the sixth, often added after the name of influential gozoku (local ruling families, who are not related to the royal family) (e.g., NOMI no Sukune, TAKENOUCHI no Sukune, TAKARI no Sukune and so on).

sen.j: このことから、允恭天皇も元来は葛城（奈良県御所市）出身の地方豪族で、反正天皇の崩後に王位を簒奪したのではないかと見る説が存在する。
sen.e: From the above, there is a theory which postulates that Emperor Ingyo was originally a member of a local ruling family from Katsuragi (Gose City, Nara Prefecture) and, after demise of Emperor Hanzei, he seized the royal throne.

Therefore, there is a theory which regards the Emperor Ingyo as originally being a member of gozoku from Katsuragi (Gose City, Nara Prefecture), and presumed that after the death of Emperor Hanzei, he may possibly have usurped the throne.
sen.cmt: 表現・用語上の修正を加えました
sen.e: Therefore, there is a theory which regards the Emperor Ingyo as originally being a member of gozoku from Katsuragi (Gose City, Nara Prefecture), and presumed that after the death of Emperor Hanzei, he may possibly have usurped the throne.

sen.j: その傍証として、ワケ号を負う履中・反正とは根本的に異質な名であることや、この2天皇から病気を理由に愚か者として軽蔑されていて、即位が円滑に行われなかったという所伝、当時の有力豪族たる蘇我・葛城氏の系譜に、武内宿禰の子として若子宿禰という人物の存在が伝えられ、時代が重なること、さらには、倭王済（允恭）と倭王珍（反正に比定される）の血縁関係を記さない『宋書』の問題などが挙げられる。
sen.e: Collateral evidences for that include a fact that his name is fundamentally different from those of Richu and Hanzei which bear the title of wake, a legend that he was despised by these two Emperors as a fool because of his illness and his accession to the throne did not proceed smoothly, a story told in genealogies of Soga and Katsuragi clans, the influential Gozoku of the time, that there was a person by the name of WAKUGO no Sukune as a son of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune at a period which overlaps that of Ingyo, and, further, the problem in "Sungshu" that it does not describe any blood relationship between Sai, a king of Wa (Ingyo) and Chin, a king of Wa (identified with Hanzei).

Collateral evidences for that include: a fact that his name is fundamentally different from those of Richu and Hanzei which bear the title of wake (which means 'coming into being'); a legend that he was despised by these two Emperors as a fool because of his illness and his accession to the throne did not proceed smoothly; a story told in genealogies of Soga and Katsuragi clans which were the influential Gozoku of the time that there was reportedly a person known as WAKUGO no Sukune who was a son of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune at a period which overlaps that of Ingyo; and a problem in the "So-jo" (the Book of Song) that it does not describe any blood relationship between King Sai of Wa (Ingyo) and King Chin of Wa (identified with Hanzei).
sen.cmt: 形式・表現・用語上の修正を加えました。「ワケ」号は湧く、発生する、生まれるの意味であることを補足しました。参考：http://koto8.net/kodai4/kodai5/kodaigo02.html
sen.e: Collateral evidences for that include: a fact that his name is fundamentally different from those of Richu and Hanzei which bear the title of wake (which means 'coming into being'); a legend that he was despised by these two Emperors as a fool because of his illness and his accession to the throne did not proceed smoothly; a story told in genealogies of Soga and Katsuragi clans which were the influential Gozoku of the time that there was reportedly a person known as WAKUGO no Sukune who was a son of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune at a period which overlaps that of Ingyo; and a problem in the "So-jo" (the Book of Song) that it does not describe any blood relationship between King Sai of Wa (Ingyo) and King Chin of Wa (identified with Hanzei).

sen.j: 恵我長野北陵（えがのながののきたのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: He was entombed in Ega no nagano no kita no misasagi (mausoleum).
He was entombed in Ega no nagano no kita no misasagi (mausoleum).
He was entombed in Ega no nagano no kita no misasagi (mausoleum).

sen.j: 同陵は、大阪府藤井寺市国府一丁目にある国府市野山古墳（前方後円墳・全長228m）に比定されている。
sen.e: The mausoleum is identified with Kokufu Ichinomiya kofun (tumulus) (a large keyhole-shaped tumulus; total length, 228 m) located at 1-chome, Kokufu, Fujiidera City, Osaka Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 「国府市野山古墳」は、ウェブ調査からから「こくふいちのみや古墳」と読みました。
sen.e: The mausoleum is identified with Kokufu Ichinomiya kofun (tumulus) (a large keyhole-shaped tumulus of 228 meters in the total length) located at 1-chome, Kokufu, Fujiidera City, Osaka Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 形式・表現上の修正を加えました
sen.e: The mausoleum is identified with Kokufu Ichinomiya kofun (tumulus) (a large keyhole-shaped tumulus of 228 meters in the total length) located at 1-chome, Kokufu, Fujiidera City, Osaka Prefecture.
